description: You are a skilled hand-weaver in rural England, 1780. Most villagers farm or raise sheep, but you've built a reputation for fine linen and wool cloth. You own two looms in your cottage, employ three apprentices, and sell at the weekly market. Life is modest but stable — until whispers of 'steam looms' reach the village…
disruption: Steam-powered factories are opening in Manchester and Leeds…
question: Why are your customers suddenly buying cheaper cloth?
answers: A new fashion banned colorful cloth
Power looms produce fabric 20× faster than human hands
The king raised taxes on hand-made goods
fact: Between 1780 and 1810, British handloom weavers fell from ~250,000 to under 10,000.

description: You now run a successful gas-lamp manufacturing and street-lighting business in London. Your factory employs 180 workers producing lamps and mantles. Electric bulbs are still expensive toys for the rich — until Edison and Swan perfect them…
disruption: Electric lighting is sweeping cities overnight…
question: Why did cities stop buying your gas lamps?
answers: Electric bulbs are brighter, safer, and cheaper to run
Gas lamps were outlawed for being too beautiful
fact: By 1910, gas lighting jobs in the U.S. dropped 90%. Ice delivery collapsed with electric refrigerators.

description: Your family owns the largest livery stable, carriage works, and hay dealership in a growing Midwestern town. You shoe 200 horses a week and rent carriages to doctors and merchants — until Ford's Model T rolls off the line…

question: Why are your stables suddenly empty?
answers: A horse plague killed all animals
fact: U.S. horse population: 25 million (1915) → under 3 million (1960).

fact: Millions of dedicated typist jobs vanished in the 1980s–90s.
